website_summaries.verdict: This pocket field guide tells you everything you need to know – and more – about the common species it includes. Unfortunately, it's not terribly thorough.
pros: Descriptive information and key reptile and amphibian facts listed in this colorful reference book
Includes photography, graphics, and art to identify species from different angles
cons: Covers fewer than 150 of the several hundred reptile and amphibian species in North America

customer_reviews.title: A real Pocket book
customer_reviews.text: They don't make these anymore, so it was great to find this for my 6 year old grandson who loves amphibians and snakes. He specifically asked for a pocket size since he wants to take it with him everywhere. It is the perfect size and of course pictures are great.
customer_reviews.author: Ms. Need to Know

customer_reviews.title: great
customer_reviews.text: good to keep in your camping bag, i live in a wet and thick wooded part of florida and there are tons of differant snaked and other reptiles, its good to know how to identify them and know whether to avoid them or not. its small and feels well built
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Animal lovers must have
customer_reviews.text: Awesome field guide for identifying stuff in the field in North America has most common species and has great pictures and info snippets. Recommend this to any animal lover
customer_reviews.author: Sydney

customer_reviews.title: Great 'advanced' book for my soon to be 5 y.o. grandson
customer_reviews.text: Great "advanced" book for my soon to be 5 y.o. grandson. Doesn't have every creature in there but it has lots of interesting ones and he's ID'd quite a few from his daily New Orleans excursion to the field across the street including a small gecko and a toad which provided a lesson for him when said toad ate said gecko!
customer_reviews.author: R. C. Hatfield

customer_reviews.title: Poor index--poor guide overall
customer_reviews.text: You have to know the scientific name of the species to use the index. Not really an adequate backpack nor beginners reference, with very few details.
customer_reviews.author: NorCal Resident

customer_reviews.title: Handy Guide
customer_reviews.text: A bit pricey, but also very handy. I purchased this guide for my grandson who loves the pictures and reading about each creature with his parents and grandparents.
customer_reviews.author: Raymond Bial

customer_reviews.title: Fine for fingers, not amphibian toes or snake armpits
customer_reviews.text: Great resource. It would be 5 stars if the pages were water resistant like other field guides.
customer_reviews.author: smack

customer_reviews.title: Great for school project
customer_reviews.text: Great pocket guide for my son's school project. Very colorful & informative. Just enough information for a report.

customer_reviews.title: Great little book!
customer_reviews.text: Great pictures and info for my Grandchildren to take on their nature walks.
customer_reviews.author: lcook

customer_reviews.title: Ok for beginners
customer_reviews.text: If you are just starting to get interested in reptiles and amphibians, this is a good starter guide for in the field. Pros: Small size for fitting in pocket or purse. Color photos of each species on every page. Good quick source of information (habitat, range and food.) Cons: Many photos show just the head of the critter, not the whole body. Illustrations on each page show the entire critter, but not much detail. Habitat descriptions don't include range map, just text. Suggested improvements: Put a code on each page that when scanned, provides a link to more photos and information. For someone who is advanced with knowledge of reptiles and amphibians, this won't be of much help.
customer_reviews.author: slim

customer_reviews.title: nice book for young herpers
customer_reviews.text: Reptiles & Amphibians of North America is a nice book for young herpers who are interested in learning about these animals. The book contains a lot of pictures and is easy to understand. It is small and concise, making it easy to carry the book around in the field. However, it does not include all of the species found in North America and does not include range maps. Because of this, I would not recommend using this book to identify reptile and amphibian species.
customer_reviews.author: Becker

customer_reviews.title: Another Good Nature Book From National Geographic
customer_reviews.text: Like all National Geographic guides I have seen and used this is a well designed, organized and produced volume. The language and style of the book it easy for all to access including children of upper elementary age though it is appropriate for adult users as well. This is a great starting point for those who want to begin learning about reptiles and amphibians. The pocket size makes it easy to stow in a backpack providing quick reference for hikers.
customer_reviews.author: Falkor

customer_reviews.title: Great Guidebook
customer_reviews.text: This is a very nice pocket identification guide. Clear, concise pictures and illustrations with easy to read facts and information. Each critter has it's own page, so there is no flipping back and forth like the Audubon guides. Small enough for a field jacket pocket. There are 148 species listed, so due to the small size it is somewhat limited in scope.
customer_reviews.author: Juanita Floyd

customer_reviews.title: A compact and useful guide
customer_reviews.text: Pros: Small and sturdy. Fits in your pocket. Good tips on where to locate these animals, and their unique behaviors. Most of the reptiles and amphibians I have encountered are listed here. Cons: Uses a verbal description of range instead of an easier to read map.
customer_reviews.author: Ludix

customer_reviews.title: Very Handy
customer_reviews.text: My former pocket guide is really really really old. This one is larger so not quite so tiny printwise. Kind of large for a pocket guide but the pictures are excellent. Love the photos and the detailed illustrations. Updated info includes non native species that have invaded certain areas sometimes threatening indigenous wildlife. Very handy for dealing with boy scouts and other young males.
customer_reviews.author: VW Smith

product_meta.title: National Geographic Pocket Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of North America
